div.head: Report:
div.p: The experiment was devoted to the temperature-dependent structural investigation of synthetic tetrahedrites. We planned to study two compounds, Cu 12 Sb 4 S 13 and Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 . The key question concerning the former compound was the investigation of its structural change across the metal-semiconductor transition (MST) at T ~ 85 K. Additionally, the hightemperature studies of the compound were planned. In regard to the Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 compound, we planned to focus on the detection of an extra-copper site in the tetrahedrite structure and, besides, on the study of the compound in the wide temperature range.

Cu 12 Sb 4 S 13 (space group I-43m), the copper-poor tetrahedrite (see structure view in Fig. 1), is a compound with promising thermoelectric properties, undergoing a phase transition at T ~ 85 K, according to the heat-capacity, electrical resistivity, and magnetic susceptibility measurements. However, no information on structural changes across this transition was reported. Thus, during the experiment at ID 22, we examined the lowtemperature crystal structure of the compound. Neither a structural transformation was found upon passing the MST transition, nor any sign of superstructure peaks or reflection splitting was observed. However, the change in the unit cell parameter (see Fig. 2) clearly pointed to structural changes upon passing the MST temperature. The analysis of the interatomic distances showed that these changes are associated with the shift of the Cu(2) atom out of the S 3 triangle plane. Moreover, high values of the atomic displacement parameters (ADPs) for the Cu(2) and S(2) atoms, increasing sharply below the MST temperature, were found. Thus, the positions of Cu(2) and S(2) were examined in more detail for temperatures below the MST. The best refinement results were obtained for the model with S(2) shifting to the 25% occupied 8-fold x,x,-x position. Therefore, below the MST temperature the S(2) atoms are displaced from their high-symmetry 2a site towards the triangle plane of the Cu(2) 6 octahedra, with the displacement increasing upon cooling. At the same time, the Cu(2) atoms move closer to their ideal 12e position in the center of the triangular S 3 plane, which is composed of two S(1) and one S(2) atoms (see Fig. 3). These results are published in Chem. Mater., DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b02720 (2016).
The investigation of the Cu 12 Sb 4 S 13 structure at high temperatures showed that the compound melts with decomposition in the temperature range between 540 and 570 K.

Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 , copper-rich tetrahedrite, is the purely Cu 1+ compound that likely has diamagnetic insulating properties. Similar to Cu 12 Sb 4 S 13 , Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 crystallizes in the cubic unit cell with the same I43m space group, albeit with the slightly larger lattice parameter, around 10.42 Å vs. 10.32 Å. The most important question concerning the Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 structure is the position of 2 extra Cu atoms, compared with the parent Cu 12 Sb 4 S 13 structure.

Surprisingly, we were unable to detect any additional position of Cu in Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 . The two extra Cu atoms per formula unit were simply missing in the refinement. This may be related to the presence of foreign phases in the sample under investigation. Additionally, the extra Cu atoms can be randomly distributed within the tetrahedrite structure. Therefore, further experiments focusing on the local structure may be interesting.
High-temperature investigations of Cu 14 Sb 4 S 13 showed that the compound melts with decomposition above 500 K. Fig. 3 Structural changes of the tetrahedrite structure, accompanying the MST.
